items.title: Who are tattoos really for?
items.author: Laura
items.description:
There are two arrows inked into my left wrist. On the right, a balanced set of scales. An elegant crown dominates my shoulder blade. Birds flit across my collarbone, and a crab lives on the inside of my arm.

My tattoos bear meaningful complexities. They are homages to my family and my friends, my beliefs and my experiences. I designed each one myself, and not a stroke of my pen was without meaning. But the actual marks remain simple to those unfamiliar with intimate details of my life. They are not relatable, not easily explained.

And so I have come to dread attempting to explain them. In many of my first encounters with people, they ask me to do so. They expect quick responses that will casually extend the conversation. But these are symbols for intangible, unique aspects of my existence I cannot name in just a few words.

At the same time, these people do not know me. They don’t know my experiences. The stories behind each tattoo will mean nothing to them. So I tell them the crown is for my family’s name, the birds an homage to my teenage obsession with boyband One Direction. I say these things and people ooh and aww and laugh as appropriate. But I feel like I am lying.

I got sick of that feeling. For about three days I tried to stop answering the question. But nobody let me succeed. It was hard to say “I don’t want to tell you” in a way that wasn’t rude. Those generalized explanations were eventually coaxed out of me.

And so, sometimes, I wonder who my tattoos are for. When I inked my most personal experiences onto my skin for the world to see, did I expect to keep them private? Is body art something to be examined and analyzed as you would a cartoon in a newspaper, or a commercial on TV? Why do I owe near strangers these explanations?

No, I don’t regret any of my ink. This form of self-expression has become vital to me. What I love and what I believe can be a physical part of my body. But though my tattoos are on display for all to see, they are not public. Their meanings belong to me.
